question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the way language acts as an integral part of social systems, how people are consistently pushed to the margins of society based on discriminatory regimes, and how the sociopolitical borders in place are governing forces.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about discourse, how language is a form of capital, and how dramatically language affects our society, specifically in regard to migration. I gained skills in reading, understanding, and writing about complex academic text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the intentionality behind the injustices in our society, and how to examine how we might be unconsciously upholding power imbalances. Specifically language has a lot of unintentional power.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the foundational background of language. I learned how language intersects with margins and borders. I learned how linguistic capital affects social justice

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Difference in classes, every single class felt the same with group discussion and after a couple weeks it became very boring and underwhelming no matter what the topic we were discussing. The readings felt long and repetitive and not essential for discussion as you could comment on discussion just from common sense limiting my ability to always remain engaged. We often spent time discussing the reliability of the texts we were reading which leads to the feeling that there was no point in reading if we are going to continue to go against everything in the text. Most classes felt scattered not following a set plan which made the class had to follow and remain engaged. I would keep the small group discussion for some topics but for every single one makes the topics less engaging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
This course goes over a variety of topics in cognitive neuroscience, linguistics, and musicology. It is truly a multidisciplinary course incorporating different aspects of various specified topics within bigger domains, such as looking at theoretical linguistics and forensics linguistics, among others. This class also familiarizes students with reading scientific literature. We had to read a handful of papers on Neuroimaging techniques, the white matter integrity of the brain, and how it is affected by multilingualism and musicianship. The class covers the following topics:
- Neuroimaging techniques
- Cognitive Neuroscience
- Linguistics
There is much intersection between these concepts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Research methods and designs.
Reading and analyzing/critiquing research papers and primary sources.
Neuroscience, cognitive neuroscience.
Linguistics.
Affects of multilingualism and multi-musicianship on the brain.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Interpreting research papers about neuroscience, cognition and language. Developing critical thinking regarding traditional views of brain function. Acquiring definitions for key concepts in cognition, such as language, speech communities, signification.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to communicate in class and how read heavy scientific readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how language functions in the brain, that it is a bilateral process, and that there are no such things as critical periods for language learning. I learned about the Jacobsonain Speech Model which explains how communication and language work. I learned that many of the processes in the subcortical white matter are multimodal, like language, and that multilingualism can improve and maintain subcortical white matter fiber tracks over time.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to read research papers and develop an understanding of how someone also learned how to synthesize information together from various sources to extract a holistic well-rounded background on an area of interest. Another thing I learned is how to consider many different angles and aspects of the same subject. There are so many considerations in every field—everything is interdisciplinary. This course truly highlights that fact.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the importance of reading primary research from established figures in the field. I also learned the importance of speech communities and communities of practice and how it's sometimes important to be wary of papers authored by those who are not a part of the community of practice they are dealing with. I also learned a lot about basic neurobiology, linguistics, and the integration of the two through learning about neuroimaging techniques and existing research.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a very interesting and intellectual course that I'd recommend for anyone interested in neuroscience, research, or linguistics. This course gives you a deeper understanding of how language works in the brain and trains you to read and analyze difficult scientific research articles. The class isn't too difficult but does include a good amount of reading and memorization. This class is designed to help you learn and build good study habits and learning habits for the rest of college.
